item.title: Greg Wilson: Allocating Responsibilities (rotating decomposition is my favourite)
item.description:
Pontifications

  • "Finally, there is rotating decomposition: everyone does one task for a few weeks, then a different task for the new few, and so on. This is initially less productive in absolute terms than either of the preceding strategies, since the team has to pay for ramp-up several times over. In the long term, though, it outperforms the alternatives: it is more robust (having a team member drop out is less harmful), and if everyone on the team is familiar with every aspect of the software, they can all contribute to design and debugging sessions."<— Read the whole thing: Greg Wilson: Allocating Responsibilities

item.title: Simon Willison: Better presentations through story telling: AIM, Star (and bonus: sparklines)
item.description:
Pontifications

  • "Every talk should start with an AIM: Audience, Intent, Message...Try to include at least one STAR moment—Something They’ll Always Remember. ... Presentations are most interesting if they are structured with contrasts. ... When giving a talk, position your audience as the hero. They start in position of comfort and safety. Your job is to call them to adventure"<— Read the whole thing: Simon Willison: Better presentations through story telling (and bonus: Creating Moments of Impact: Using Sparklines for Strategic Conversations)

item.title: textpipe: clean and extract metadata from text
item.description:
Pontifications

  • "textpipe is a Python package for converting raw text in to clean, readable text and extracting metadata from that text. Its functionalities include transforming raw text into readable text by removing HTML tags and extracting metadata such as the number of words and named entities from the text." <- From python pip docs for textpipe
  • Look like this could be useful for extracting tags from support forum questions!

item.title: Aaron Parecki: Tools and apps for home automation without relying on cloud services
item.description:
Pontifications

  • "Here is a list of all the various home automation tools and apps I use. Overall, my main goal is to have everything running locally, without relying on cloud services. This pretty much rules out all products by Amazon and Google, and many others. It also means sometimes it's more work to get things running, but it's worth it in the end." <- From Home Automation
  • Not sure I want to do this with or without the cloud :-) Curmudgeon-ish I know :-)
